Economic abstraction deals with the idea that something other than the native coin can be used to pay miners. It's technically possible to do this in PoW chains today but is complex.

One of my favorite parts of EIP-1559 is it kills EA and makes ETH necessary on the base layer.

1105268386861322240.text: Actually, a full node contains the full state. An archive node additionally contains historic state snapshots for every past block, allowing you to turn back time to any block without having to validate the chain from an earlier snapshot or genesis. It's a caching mechanism.

1107801349922537473.text:
Comparing ETH issuance reductions to BTC halvenings:

BTC (per block):
*50 BTC - Jan 2009
*25 BTC - Nov 2012
*12.5 BTC - Aug 2016

ETH (per block):
*5 ETH - July 2015
*3 ETH - Oct 2017
*2 ETH - Feb 2019

Notice a pattern?

(h/t @econoar for the chart)pic.twitter.com/LQGfZRtYHB

1101252504950632449.text:
One of the reasons $ETH might accrue more value is that it has become a verifiable form of collateral for borrowing and investing.

You can lock it up in a smart contract to prove your commitment to a financial transaction. The contract can liquidate it if you fail to deliver.
